The surest sign of regime change is when they begin to attack statues .
Americans value this as much as any other - hence the carefully staged fall of Saddam Hussein on the Bay of Baghdad in 2003 .

Stephen Miller , one of the key ideologues of the Trump regime , surely knew what he did when he took a symbolic axe in a heated dispute with Jim Acosta of CNN about the president ’ s proposals for drastic curtailment of legal immigration with the Statue of Liberty .

But he took on their significance , and in particular the importance that was attributed to her when the famous poem of Emma Lazarus 1903 , 17 years after the completion of the monument , was added to his base .

The poem you refer to , which was added later and is not part of the original Statue of Liberty . "
Miller is factually correct , but as he himself put it , it is not really about history .

It is about the contemporary resonance of the eloquent words of Lazarus , the only one in which a state not only invites any old immigrants , but the poorest of the poor : " Your dead , your poor , / your afflicted masses who yearn to breathe freely , / the miserable waste of your rich coasts . "

Miller did not engage in literary criticism - he made it clear that these people are not welcome to Trump ’ s US .

Lazarus - and their friends who sought to put their words on the ground after their death - knew very well that they had a highly political act .
The sculpture should show the connections between French and American Republicanism by representing female embodiment of freedom in a playful classical image .
Lazarus changed this meaning : In her poem the female figure is no longer abstract - she got a voice .
And she gives herself a very different name : mother of exile .

And just as Lazarus changed the meaning of the statue , the people of the right wing wanted to change it for a long time .

The significance of the statue is absolutely a question of the position of perception .
The great imaginative act of Lazarus was to see it as seen by the exhausted , miserable but hopeful people after long and often terrible trips on the decks of ships .
It is really about seeing the world from the perspective of people seeking refuge and improving their lives .
